For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Product of Ideals need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a finitely generated module involves the existence of a finite set of generators that can generate all elements of the module through linear combinations over the ring. This definition focuses on the ability to express every element of the module as a linear combination of a finite number of elements from the module itself, with coefficients in the ring.

On the other hand, the product of ideals is a concept specific to the operation within the ring structure, particularly involving the multiplication of elements from two different ideals to form a new ideal. This operation is related to the ring's multiplicative structure and does not directly influence the definition or understanding of what constitutes a finitely generated module.

Therefore, the concept of the product of ideals is not necessary for defining or understanding a finitely generated module. The definition of a finitely generated module is self-contained with respect to the module and its relationship with the ring, independent of the specific operations like the product of ideals within the ring.
